animal_concentrations.References: (1) Gauthier LT et al; Environ Sci Pollut Res Int 43: 312-317 (2009) (2) Gentes M-L et al; Environ Sci Technol 46: 9735-9744 (2012) (3) Tomy GT et el; Environ Sci Technol 42(2): 543-549 (2008)
animal_concentrations.Value: A concentration range of 0.04 to 3.44 ng/g wet weight was reported for 1,2-dibromo-4-(1,2-dibromoethyl)cyclohexane in the eggs of colonial populations of Great Lakes herring gulls (Larus argentatus), collected in 1982 to 2006(1). A concentration range for alpa-1,2-dibromo-4-(1,2-dibromoethyl)cyclohexane of not detected to 0.20 ng/g wet weight was reported in 3 of 28 liver samples from urban-feeding ring-billed gulls (L. delawarensis) from Ile Deslauries on the St. Lawrence River, downstream from Montreal, Quebec, Canada. It was not detected in 30 plasma samples; sampling was conducted from April-June 2010(2). A concentration range of not detected to 11.3 ng/g lipid weight was reported in blubber from Canadian Arctic beluga (Delphinapterus leucas) collected from 23 male animals taken 2003-2006(3).

Wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) are an important source of anthropogenic chemicals, including organic flame retardants (FRs). Limited studies indicate birds can be exposed to FRs by feeding from waters receiving WWTP effluent or in fields receiving biosolids. Expanding on our earlier study, 47 legacy and 18 new FR contaminants were characterized in the eggs of insectivorous tree swallows (Tachycineta bicolor) feeding in water bodies receiving effluent from two WWTPs and compared to those from a reference site 19 km downstream of the nearest WWTP. Of the FRs measured, polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) dominated the FR profile, specifically BDE-47, -99, -100, -153, -154, with considerably lower concentrations of hexabromocyclododecane (HBCDD), BDE-183 and BDE-209; each detected in 96-100% of the eggs overall except HBCDD (83%). FR concentrations were usually significantly greater in eggs from the secondary WWTP versus the tertiary WWTP and/or reference site. Despite low detection rates, concentrations of new FRs, specifically pentabromobenzyl acrylate (PBBA), 1,2,-bis-(2,4,6-tribromophenoxy)ethane (BTBPE), bis(2-ethylhexyl)-tetrabromophthalate (BEHTBP), tetrabromo-o-chlorotoluene (TBCT), hexabromobenzene (HBB), alpha- and beta-1,2-dibromo-4-(1,2-dibromoethyl)-cyclohexane (DBE-DBCH), were greater than HBCDD or BDE-209. Additional evidence that WWTPs are an important source of exposure to new FR contaminants for birds utilizing associated water bodies is that only the WTTP eggs, not the reference eggs, had measureable concentrations of PBBA, TBCT, BEHTBP, HBB, alpha-DBE-DBCH, 2,2',4,5,5'-pentabromobiphenyl (BB-101), pentabromoethyl benzene (PBEB), 2,4,6-tribromophenyl allyl ether (TBPAE), and tetrabromo-p-xylene (pTBX). Our study suggests that WWTPs are an important source of legacy and new FR contaminants for birds consuming prey that are associated with WWTP out-flows.

1,2-Dibromo-4-(1,2-dibromoethyl)cyclohexane concentrations in blubber from Finless porpoises (Neophocaena phocaenoides) and Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins (Sousa chinensis) from the South China Sea between 2005 and 2015(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Zheng G et al; Environ Sci Technol 52: 4632-40 (2018)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: beta-1,2-Dibromo-4-(1,2-dibromoethyl)cyclohexane concentrations in plankton, invertebrates and fish from Lake Taihu, South China, collected in August 2014 and May 2015. The method detection limits (MDL) were 1.6 and 48 pg/g wet weight (ww), respectively. alpha-1,2-Dibromo-4-(1,2-dibromoethyl)cyclohexane was only detected in silver fish, concentration range of 134-208 pg/g ww(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Nyholm JR et al; Sci Total Environ 443: 307-14 (2013) (2) Yang R et al; Environ Sci Technol 46(6): 3119-3126 (2012) (3) Zhu B et al; Chemosphere 93(3): 555-560 (2013)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: 1,2-Dibromo-4-(1,2-dibromoethyl)cyclohexane was tested for but not detected in sediment samples collected near suspected sources in Lake Mjosa, Drammensfjorden and Tromso, Norway sampled in late summer and autumn, 2009(1). 1,2-Dibromo-4-(1,2-dibromoethyl)cyclohexane was detected in 85% of 144 sediment samples from throughout the Great Lakes. Reported ranges were (ng/g dry weight): 0.05-0.31 (Superior); 0.06-0.47 (Michigan); 0.08-0.55 (Huron); 0.66-0.97 (Erie); 1.0-1.54 (Ontario). Sampling was conducted from August 1-25, 2007(2). A detection frequency of 92% with a mean concentration of 0.844 ng/g dry weight (range <0.150-2.02 ng/g dw) was reported in marine sediment of the Yangtze River Delta (YRD) region, East China, sampled in summer, 2011. A detection frequency of 100% with a mean concentration of 3.74 ng/g dry weight (range <0.856-8.50 ng/g dw) was reported in Yangtze River sediment(3).
SOIL: 1,2-Dibromo-4-(1,2-dibromoethyl)cyclohexane was tested for but not detected in soil from Stockholm, Sweden, collected from April 30 to June 4, 2012(1).
